description: This is a technique for isolating phage from agar plates.  When working with lytic phage, well-isolated, cleared areas in a lawn of bacteria (called plaques) are removed from the agar (by coring with a sterile pipette) and used to infect fresh bacteria in liquid medium.  The lysed culture can be used for a new plaque assay after 0.2 um filtering to remove residual bacteria.  New phage are "plaque-purified" a minimum of three times before they are considered to be free of other phage.

components.data: Poke the plaque in the agarose with the tip of an autoclaved Pasteur pipette to core it out drawing agarose chunks into the pipette
components.name: Description

source_data.annotation:
Can you use sterilized tooth-picks?
Would be cheaper.

source_data.body:
Can you use sterilized tooth-picks?
Would be cheaper.

comments.affiliation: Matthew Sullivan Lab, University of Arizona, The Ohio State University
comments.name: Bonnie Poulos
comments.comment_text: We have not used sterile toothpicks for extracting virus plaques from agar overlays.  Toothpicks have been used successfully for transferring bacteria from colonies, so in theory they should work to pick up viruses from plaques.  Recommend comparing the two methods first with a purified virus to determine whether recoveries differ.  Chances are fewer particles will get transferred using a toothpick than when using a pipette to core out a piece of the agar.  (If a toothpick is used, then this would not actually be a "coring" technique.)
comments.body: We have not used sterile toothpicks for extracting virus plaques from agar overlays.  Toothpicks have been used successfully for transferring bacteria from colonies, so in theory they should work to pick up viruses from plaques.  Recommend comparing the two methods first with a purified virus to determine whether recoveries differ.  Chances are fewer particles will get transferred using a toothpick than when using a pipette to core out a piece of the agar.  (If a toothpick is used, then this would not actually be a "coring" technique.)

components.data: Inoculate 2-5 ml dense cells (whatever is available) with the cyanophage plaque by pipetting up and down a few times
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Inoculate 2-5 ml dense cells (whatever is available) with the cyanophage plaque by pipetting up and down a few times

components.data: Let this sit in the incubator for 60 minutes to adsorb and then dilute with about 25 ml media
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Let this sit in the incubator for 60 minutes to adsorb and then dilute with about 25 ml media

components.data: Do this in parallel to a control tube of just cells and observe the cyanophage inoculated cultures for lysis (clearing) relative to the controls
components.name: Description
